description: This fieldwork course focuses on development of a systematic approach to advanced physical assessment, the use of diagnostic technologies and the development of a diagnostic reasoning as it applies to patient management of the acutely ill and injured. Emphasis is placed on development of competence to perform a comprehensive history and decision making for the management of acutely ill patients.
name: ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY & CLINICAL DECISIONS IN ACUTE CARE (60 CLINICAL HOURS)

section.name: ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY & CLINICAL DECISIONS IN ACUTE CARE (60 CLINICAL HOURS)
ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY & CLINICAL DECISIONS IN ACUTE CARE (60 CLINICAL HOURS)

values.comments:
This is a practical course aimed at developing a systematic approach to a patient’s physical assessment utilizing diagnostic technologies and reasoning. Instructors are hoping that students will be able to perform a comprehensive history and be able to make decisions/manage acutely ill patients.

Most students found the content of the course to be enjoyable, especially the laboratory component. Many students praised the guest speakers in the class, characterizing them as “excellent” and “great.” Students generally found the clinical component of the course to be enriching, but reported that there was not enough instructor supervision or assistance.

Many students reported that while Professor Griffith was an “adequate” lecturer, she was somewhat “dry” and “monotone” in nature. Some students said that Professor Griffith was not open to taking suggestions about how to alter the course or incorporate ideas on how to improve lecturing and presenting techniques. A number of students also found Professor Griffith to be too critical of their previous experiences and knowledge of the subject material to apply it to her class. Furthermore, some students also reported having difficulty contacting and meeting with Professor Griffith when they had a concern or question regarding the material covered in class.

This class is designed for graduate and post-graduate students with previous field experience. Several students reported that Professor Griffith graded “subjectively,” with some students “receiving different grades despite having written the same thing” on quizzes and exams. There was a mixed response as to the value of the course; some students said the course was an overall positive learning experience while others claimed they did not learn much from it.
